text: I've been using slack for what feels like years, I am in 10 slacks at the moment and the slack bot treats me as a newbie on every single one. When coding is hard and complex, the nice to have features that seem obvious are left out it seems

text: This reminded me of a talk by Alan Kay where he takes one 'app' - an animation - and connects it to another app - a picture editor. By exposing the methods of the animation and live binding it to the editor, he is able to construct an ensemble where one frame of the animation can be live edited in the picture editor, while the animation is playing. The main point was that these 'apps' were not designed with each other in mind, yet were able to work together. These were not apps, really - they were just objects with views. For them to work together, they were both introspectable (could see their methods), built from the same substrate (same smalltalk system) and shared the notion of some types (e.g. a picture itself).

elements.text: This reminded me of a talk by Alan Kay where he takes one 'app' - an animation - and connects it to another app - a picture editor. By exposing the methods of the animation and live binding it to the editor, he is able to construct an ensemble where one frame of the animation can be live edited in the picture editor, while the animation is playing. The main point was that these 'apps' were not designed with each other in mind, yet were able to work together. These were not apps, really - they were just objects with views. For them to work together, they were both introspectable (could see their methods), built from the same substrate (same smalltalk system) and shared the notion of some types (e.g. a picture itself).

text: Another angle to think about this, which I really like - is 'universal hypermedia'. Instead of thinking of apps, we think of a virtual shared world of hypermedia objects. Not only are objects link-lable, even slices or points within an object (e.g. a snippet in an essay) are link-able. A time point within a video becomes a point within that hypermedia object.

elements.text: Another angle to think about this, which I really like - is 'universal hypermedia'. Instead of thinking of apps, we think of a virtual shared world of hypermedia objects. Not only are objects link-lable, even slices or points within an object (e.g. a snippet in an essay) are link-able. A time point within a video becomes a point within that hypermedia object.

text: I've been thinking about the same but using another metaphor, fractal applications. Applications all the way down! what if every single part of an application was also a self contained application, whatever view of the application you are using could be just a part of other applications for other people, applications have no root or center. Instead of getting rid of applications we make them reusable.
